description.text:
Mantic is a company that makes great war game miniatures for decent prices, unlike certain other companies who shall not be named that charge way too much. Their miniatures are often designed with a tiny +/- 15mm round base that fits into a corresponding socket on their proper diameter game bases.  
Maybe you want to use a different base size than the one included, or maybe you got one of their Christmas Crazy Boxes and need to base your miniatures. You probably should consider ordering a package of the real thing from the Mantic site if you have a lot of miniatures because they're a cool company, but this could tide you over if you only need a few.  
Note that the hexagonal bases are drawn at 25mm edge-to-edge. If this is not accurate, let me know and I will update the files accordingly.

comments.text: For anyone who reads the comments, I cannot recommend the Crazy Xmas boxes enough. You pay between $30-40 USD, and get what is easily $75+ of models. The first time I ordered it I got around ~110 models and a messenger bag to boot, and this last year I got around 50 models, including a large vehicle and nearly a dozen large-base figurines (That all by itself would have been $50 from any other company, ignoring the other 20-25ish models of regular size I got as well).
comments.author: darkPrince010

comments.text: Yes, Mantic is awesome. Is there any chance you have the dimensions for the hexagonal Dreadball bases? I'll add that one too as soon as I have the size.
comments.author: darkPrince010

comments.text:
Mantic's site says they're 25mm, although unfortunately I don't have one in person to give you better measurements.
http://www.manticgames.com/mantic-shop/dreadball/accessories/product/mantic-hex-bases-bundle-24.htmlhttp://www.manticgames.com/man...
comments.author: Tothe

comments.text: A facebooker says 15mm along each side, so I am assuming for now that it's 25mm from edge to edge across the middle, like a hexagon circumscribed around a 25mm circle.
comments.author: darkPrince010

title: RepRapDiscount LCD Cover and Mount for Prusa i3x from DIYTechShop

description.text: RepRapDiscount LCD Cover and Mount for a DIYTechShop i3x frame (.125" thick, any frame with similar thickness should work). I also made the mounting legs shorter from a previous remix. I opened up the holes to 4mm for clearance of a 3mm or #4-40 screw so you shouldn't have to redrill. Enjoy.

print
some sanding on the slots may be needed for a nice tight fit
enjoy

description.text: Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner. Maxxxxx Head-head-headroom! Brought to you 20 minutes into the future of 1980s. The original item was a gum-filled plastic head. It has black sunglasses and yellow hair.

This is a derivative of Bre's Blender Monkey:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:895 The model is a free and open model that comes with Blender (the Blender Foundation has affectionately nicknamed the monkey Suzanne). I wanted to print it, but it could use finer detail and it also has tons of overhangs which are not good for MakerBot just yet. So I modified the design in Blender with SubSurf modifier (setting of 3 to make it much smoother), exported to stl, and then printed the model with symmetry in mind -- print exactly one half of the head, flip one of your axes to print it's mirror image, then glue or epoxy them together.

In Blender or your favorite 3D program, Cut your spherical objects (like a head) in half, bisecting the face top-down (a saggital cut). Print this first half. Now you need to print the mirror image. Do it in hardware, not software. It's much easier:
To print the other half as the EXACT mirror image, just edit your hardware settings to flip either your X or Y axis. This will make an exact mirror image object, guaranteed. No re-skeining needed. I often design mirror image objects, and this saves half the rendering, slicing, and printing time, and saves HD or SD card space too. Best of all, editing your hardware settings to flip either the X or Y axis means you can print the same .s3g file twice, taking up half the space it normally would to store/process both a left and right object. I include the .blend file in case you want to take a peek at the subsurf object (it's on layer 10... press the 0 key to go to layer 10 in Blender).

description.text: Optical Tachometer for a Bedini 3-Pole Monopole motor kit.  Bolts onto the existing extra holes, with nylon screws. Designed for 5mm IR LED & IR photo-transistor, with 5mm LED plastic holders (both from Radio Shack). There is a small channel for wires, for the back side LED or Sensor.

The tachometer wheel fits tightly onto the rotor shaft, but you may need to secure it with u-tac, tape or bolt to keep it in place. My setup worked best with the wheel as close to the IR LED as practical (see image). If the wheel was farther out, the RPM readings were inconsistent. Perhaps a larger diameter wheel, with additional gates would improve the functionality.  Additional gates increase the precision of the tachometer, as each revolution will have finer granularity, especially at higher speeds.

author: Ragnarok

title: Remix of (almost) fully printed GoPro steady cam

description.text:
Although it IS possible to print the GoPro mount which HamOp included in the original, it requires support which I wanted to avoid. Instead of this piece, I made an alternative which takes a GoPro tripod mount. (I bought one of these on EBay for 2GBP so 'yes' more non-printed parts :-) ). Other changes from HamOp's very good design ...
Amended the gimbal so that it needs two 20mm (outer) and two 16mm (inner) button head screws - no need to trim anything. The GoPro knob comes from tmoriss9: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:163883 Used a quantity of marine grade (thick) M12 washers for the weight which required a reworked weight tube to keep them in line.

I printed these parts using a 0.2mm layer height and 25% infill.  
The piece which attaches a GoPro tripod mount to the 8mm screwed rod takes two nuts. At the top is a gap for a 1/4" BSW nut into which I screwed a  1/2" BSW cap head screw using an allen key which was inserted through the 8mm hole at the bottom.  
Once the BSW screw is in place, an M8 nut is pushed into the lower of the two slots so that the M8 rod can be screwed in according to HamOp's instructions. Please note that the TRIPODMT.STL file has two single layer support diaphragms  which need to be  drilled out after printing. These are needed so that the suspended holes can be formed without the need for any support material.  
The rest of the build is according to HamOp's instructions and photos.

comments.text:
Hi Alzibiff,
great remix, thank you! After the discussion with you, I took another look at the GoPro Mount and I think it should be possible to print it without support if you lay it flat on one of the smaller inclined sides (the opposite of the one where the nut goes in). I will have a deeper look into that.
regards, HamOp

description.header: Number 5 of 5 for Gyrobot's Extruder Week.
description.text:
The last extruder in this weeks range. A RichRap Quick-Fit compatible base for the attachment of two of my Micro DUAL Extruders to make a Quick-Fit QUAD. Although it looks large (105mm x 84mm), and "Micro" and "Quad" are not synonymous, it fits perfectly within the footprint of the Quick-Fit X carriage. There are also 65mm pitched M4 holes to enable it to be base mounted too. Disclaimer : As mentioned in the original thing, this quad extruder for experimentalists pushing new frontiers, as far as I know, there is no turn-key solution for quad electronics yet, so this has not been tested. I don't know if it will keep cool sufficiently but feel free to make/test and report your findings. http://www.gyrobot.co.uk
http://www.facebook.com/gyrobotuk

Print with support. Attach four of the M6 hotends (I use extended Recreus Hotends) and align the backing nuts so that they fit into the slots in the extruder bodies. The heatsinks should fit perfectly above the Quick Fit carriage aperture. The extruders are each kept in place by single M4 screws with captive nut pushed into the underside of this base. The M6 nuts on the top of the hot ends (see photo) keep the extruder from turning. I had to notch out the carriage aperture profile a little with a file/knife to clear the hotends when quick releasing.

title: NinTastic - Nintendo Style Case for the Raspberry Pi

description.header: NinTastic - Nintendo Style Case for the Raspberry Pi
description.text:
• The NinTastic case for a Raspberry Pi prints in 3 pieces that can easily snap together:
    1. Top
    2. Bottom
    3. Flap
  • Alternative flap file without the NinTastic logo here also for convenience.
  • Designed in Tinkercad.
The NinTastic case holds a Raspberry Pi: Model B and is super easy to hookup. The inputs and outputs are:

• Micro-USB Power Cable - A good example I like to use is:
    • Amazon.com - Motorola Micro USB Charger (5V, 850mA) Model:SPN5504)
  • SD card with RetroPie image. Example hardware I like to use:
    • Amazon.com: Samsung 32GB PRO SDHC
    • Amazon.com: Samsung 64GB PRO SDHC
  • USB Game Controller, example:
    • Amazon.com: SNES Retro USB Super Nintendo Controller

• HDMI output to TV. Example cable that fits the case well:
    • Amazon.com - AmazonBasics High-Speed HDMI Cable (6.5 Feet/2.0 Meters)

description.header: RetroPie - Raspberry Pi based Video Game System
description.text: This case was designed specifically in creating a RetroPie gaming system, which combines a number of video game emulator technologies into a single Raspberry Pi based solution.

• Raspberry Pi - the hardware
  • EmulationStation - the GUI menu that lets you browse between emulator systems (e.g. Nintendo, Sega Genesis, PlayStation 1, ...) and select ROMs to play. This then loads the correct emulator to play that ROM.
  • RetroArch - the emulator used by most systems within the RetroPie
  • ES-Scraper - the game box cover art and information scraping utility.

description.text:

  • ROMs folders:
    • /home/pi/RetroPie/roms/
  • Paragon ExtFS for Windows - Ext4 File Systems Read/Write on MS Windows

description.header: Fix Issue – RetroPie Freeze at the Splash Screen - Corrupt SD Card File System
description.text: Sometimes if you are directly writing files to the SD card as described above, or if you unplug the NinTastic without first shutting it down, the SD card’s file system can get a little messed up causing this problem.  No worries, its an easy fix.

• Plug regular USB keyboard into Raspberry Pi, and reboot (pull power plug and plug back in).
  • At frozen splash screen Press F4 to breakout of freeze into command prompt. Then type these two commands (pressing enter afterward):
    • fsck.ext4 -y /dev/mmcblk0p2
    • sudo shutdown -h now
    • Note, you might have to sortof type in blind. Screen might be weird, but trust that your typing is actually being entered.
  • More info: Raspberrypi.stackexchange.com - latest-noobs-goes-into-panic-after-rainbow-splash

description.header: SD Card - Expand Image to Take Up Remaining Space
description.text:
• To expand SD card image to take up remaining space on the SD Card. Example, you have a 16GB SD card .img file you’ve put onto a 32GB SD card. To expand the filesystem to take advantage of the rest of the space:
    • sudo raspi-config
    • pick "1" to expand SD card filesystem

• The NinTastic case for a Raspberry Pi prints in 3 pieces that can easily snap together:
    1. Top
    2. Bottom
    3. Flap
First, print all 3 pieces (top, bottom, and flap).

• Insert your Raspberry Pi into the Bottom piece. Raspberry Pis can be bought here:
    • Amazon.com: Raspberry Pi Model B Revision 2.0 (512MB)

• You may want to add black rubber feet to the Bottom piece, like those found here:
    • Amazon.com - Self-Adhesive Rubber Feet Black Bumpers 0.5" x 0.14" (pack of 100)

• Carefully attach the Top to the Bottom. Start from the back and work your way to the front for sliding in the little snaps that will hold the Top and Bottom together. I suggest fitting in the corners in this order:
    1. Back – HDMI side
    2. Back – non-HDMI side
    3. Front – non-HDMI side
    4. Front – HDMI side
Carefully slide the Flap into the Top, line up with 2 holes already in the Top piece.

description.header: Two color flap (different color NinTastic logo)
description.text:
• Done by printing face up (with rafts and supports), and pausing print at 96% to switch out filament for different color. As soon as it starts to print the NinTastic logo, pause the printing. Guide on doing this:
    • MakerBot Discover Quick Tip: Print Pausing – YouTube

description.header: Print Times – on a MakerBot Replicator 2

description.text: • Standard Quality (with rafts) – 1 hr 46 min
• Standard Quality (with rafts) – 2 hr 31 min

• Face up for 2 colors (with rafts and supports):
  • Standard Quality – 32 min (pause at 96% 30 min to switch color for logo)
  • High Quality – 1 hr 3 min (pause at 96% 1 hour to switch color for logo)

description.text:
This plate contains all the 3D parts you need to build a complete extruder for your printrbot in one run. It is an addition to the Printrbot Printrbot Full Build Tray (On Steroids) ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30398 ) Plus some extra's !
  • Bird-nose for easy opening of your idler ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11731 )
    • ** note : the extruder is compatible with the jhead extruder ( = UBIS extruder - stock extuder for a Printrbot ) update : all the parts are now on the Z-plane
     update 2012/10/02 : added the extruder mount, which you'll need too !
    ** update 2013/01/25 : created a new version that slices better with slic3r.

Download the most recent version ( v1.7 )
Print it , assemble it , and take a look at how to attach the bird nose to the idler screws. (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11731)

comments.author: argus0209

comments.text: Would this work in PLA?
comments.author: tenlow

comments.text:
Short answer: no.Â 
I had them printed by a friend in PLA for my first printrbot, but the heat dissipating from the hotend, the heatbed and even the stepper motor on the extruder just make the PLA soft and everything starts failing, starting with a bending idler, and ending with the gears failing because the extruder motor folds away.
Therefor I would definitely recommend printing it in ABS to save you all the trouble...
comments.author: tenlow

comments.text: The other build plate should be good for PLA though, right? All the non-extruder parts?Â
comments.author: sponnet

comments.text:
Tenlow,
I would certainly also print the x-carriage in ABS , and the x-motor block too... the stepper motors also get quite hot.
I would recommend printing everything in ABS.
comments.author: tenlow

comments.text: update : not all parts were on the Z-plane, uploaded a new version that corrects this. Enjoy !!
comments.author: sponnet

comments.text: Yeah so about 50% at printing this and the large gear does not have the M8 nut capture. Also slic3r complained when rendering it to gcode was thinking it was not a prob. But seriously either don't upload it or upload something that works.... NOT COOL!
comments.author: sponnet

comments.text: I usually check all stl files with netfabb before running them through slic3r.  You can easily rotate and move the part to get it where you want it.
comments.author: wALLe

comments.text:
I've been able to slice & print this plate, but with the current version of slic3r , it seems to slice with errors indeed. The overlap error is caused by the extruder body , I checked with netfabb.
I'll try to make a new version that slic3r can slice without problems...
comments.author: wALLe

comments.text: Sl3cer is an amazing program but what it does is pretty complicated so there will always be small issues. I suggest you split the objects up and print them individually. You will still get the overlap message but it should still print fine.
comments.author: wALLe

comments.text: I updated the plate, this version appears to slice better with slic3r. I successfully printed such a plate last night. Enjoy !

title: Bird Photo Booth Mount for 2" square post

description.text: I purchased a Bird Photo Booth from Bryson Lovett a week ago and needed some way of attaching it to what was once a bird table feeder - I had removed the table part and was left with a post which was roughly 46mm square. (A 2" square planed piece of wood). In the instructions for his Photo Booth, Bryson recommends using a tripod as a support but I wanted something more permanent in the garden so that the birds could get used to it and I could fit my GoPro camera (or iPhone) as needed. The Bird Photo Booth is described here: http://www.BirdPhotoBooth.com My mount fits to the base of the Photo Booth using a 1/4" BSW screw and then the whole assembly slots on top of the post secured by an M8 threaded rod which has a thumbwheel at both ends. (The design of which was based on a Thing from 3D_CC_design http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53680) My very first attempt at using this arrangement can be seen here: http://youtu.be/LaNMRyZQzFY noting that I have since made one or two adjustments to the position of the feed tray which should give me a better view next time our Robin comes down for a feed!).

All parts have been designed to print with a 0.2mm layer height and no support. The post mount contains a single layer support diaphragm which needs to be drilled out after printing. This is required so that a suspended hole can be formed without the need for any support material. A 1/4" BSW nut slots into the top of the mount and then a 1/4" BSW cap head bolt, 1/2" long, goes into the nut from below using an allen key. This provides the thread onto which the Bird Photo Booth can be fitted. Once on the post, mark the position of the hole needed for the M8 bolt which is used to secure the assembly and then drill this hole into the post. I made the securing bolt by printing two SpinnyNutSeparate pieces. An M8 nut fits into the top half which is then capped with the bottom half. (You may need a bit of drill bit work here to get the two halves to mate). That was my first attempt. However, since then, I have reworked the method of encapsulating the M8 nut which in my opinion is a far better solution but a wee bit more involved. Taking inspiration from Nophead's blog, http://hydraraptor.blogspot.co.uk/2014/03/buried-nuts-and-hanging-holes.html I created the Encapsulated_M8_Nut.STL
To print this, you need 0.2mm layers and a pause when the print nozzle gets to a height of 6.6mm. At this point, drop in an M8 nut (there is plenty of space) and carry on with the rest of the print. As said - this is a better idea but my original works very well and is easier to construct.

author: juniortan

description.text:
This is a printable replacement for the Roomba 5xx vacuum cleaner robot.
If this component breaks prepare your printer instead of your wallet :)

Pay special attention to the bridges. If your printer can't correctly print bridges, either use support or split this piece in two parts using the SketchUp file. Then print the small cilinder and the main component (upside down) and glue them together.
You will need the bi-colored wheel from the roomba and the small metal stick, both from the broken wheel support.

comments.text: This is amazing!  Thank you so much for making this!  The front wheel kept falling out of my roomba and it was driving me nuts searching around the house to find where it dropped.  You are a life saver!

description.text: Saw a button shaped box in John Lewis and thought it would come in handy for my mother, who is into sewing, as a button button box. So i drew one in SketchUP and printer it using my UP! Plus.... Its quite basic and over-designed for what it is, but I like it. http://www.johnlewis.com/231594349/Product.aspx

Printed at Normal speed with 0.3mm layers on my Up! Plus, took about 2hours total, should scale together quite easily.
If i get time ill remodel using better circles, as this is quite facet'ed with only 50facets per circle, the lid still fits very well though.

comments.text: I really like this box. I printed one and have been using it for years now to store my buttons in my sewing room. Getting ready to print another for a friend. Thanks!

author: Stefan123

description.text:
Designed to use the freshly charged batteries in FIFO order. It is completely modular so you can create as long as possible by printing more than one middle items.
To assemble the parts use an M4 threaded rod - I made holes for the hex nuts on the bottom parts. https://www.youmagine.com/designs/modular-fifo-aa-battery-holder

Print each part except top - there are two different "top" parts - you need only one of them, so make your choice. I made a short screencast about the design process in case you are curious: http://fns.csokolade.hu/2014/04/17/3d-nyomtatas-tervezzunk-fifo-elemtartot-aa-meretu-akksiknak/

author: beron

description.text: When I saw that someone had scanned the bust of Sappho (original here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14565), I figured, what better way to honor the 2,600 year-old poet than to turn her into a corny, towering, fantasy amazon warrior? I really couldn't think of anything else. She stands about 80mm tall, base is 45mm across. Model was uploaded to TinkerCAD and altered there. https://tinkercad.com/things/hLtBtZ4Ccxz-amazon-warrior-sappho

Printed on my Makerbot Replicator at a .10 layer height with 10% infill. Extruder temp 230, plate temp 110. She was painted in acrylics ans her base was sculpted from modeling epoxy and flocked with static grass.

comments.text: Just finished printing mine. Printed with ABS, don't have any PLA. Used a Makerbot Replicator (first gen). Needs a little smoothing, but looks great. Now to find time to paint! Thanks for a great item.
